newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ SPORT - Nash starts work on back injury.
newsitem.headline: NZ SPORT - Nash starts work on back injury.

text.p: CHRISTCHURCH, Sept 5 - While his New Zealand team-mates returned home after a squad training session last week, Dion Nash is back at the New Zealand Cricket (NZC) Academy at Lincoln University, NZPA reports.
Nash, 24, is taking the first tentative steps toward a return to the game after being sidelined since April with a back injury.

Nash is working with academy director Dayle Hadlee to overcome a problem which was never clearly pinpointed but forced him out of New Zealand's West Indies tour and the English county season with Middlesex.
"We are just starting working on a few basics," said Hadlee yesterday.

"With his bowling, he is just walking then jogging through, taking it very easily. We are having a look at technique comparing his bowling technique today to that when he took 11 wickets in the test at Lord's."

Nash will spend this week in Christchurch before returning home to his Northern Districts base where he will work on a rehabilitation programme devised by physiotherapist Graham Nuttridge and fitness expert Paul Carpinter.
Hadlee said Nash will return at regular intervals to monitor his progress.
The aim is for Nash to gradually increase the workload on his body, from bowling 100 balls this week at 25-40 percent pace to 300 a week in six weeks' time at 60-85 percent intensity.
"The person is more important than performance."
Hadlee said it would be unlikely Nash would be available for the New Zealand team's first tour this season to Sharjah and Pakistan.
"We will not be rushing him into anything. If he was ahead of schedule he could be available, but we will keep the New Zealand selectors informed."
Hadlee said Nash was one of the players to represent the future of the game here and had the potential for 10 years at the top.

Nash is not the only player working to overcome injury, with fellow pace bowler Danny Morrison recovering from an off-season groin operation and batsman Blair Pocock getting over a shoulder problem which has troubled him for the past two years.
